intro: Thaspium aureum var. involucratum, commonly known as the golden thaspium, is a flowering plant native to specific regions of North America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland or streamside habitats. Its ornamental value comes from its delicate foliage and subtle floral display.
